div1.p: Moran's translation of entries made in Rojas' journal are certified by Rojas' widow as conforming in tenor to the original.

div1.head: Entries in Ignacio Rojas' Journal or Day Book, [19--?]

head.hi:
ENTRIES COPIED FROM Dr. IGNACIO ROJAS' JOURNAL OR DAY
BOOK, WRITTEN BY HIMSELF. TRANSLATION
FROM SPANISH TO ENGLISH MADE
BY JOHN J. MORAN.

list.item:
Nov. 15, 1900: Today, for the third time, the Military Health Officers
of the American Army entered the San José farm, by agreement with the lessee,
Don Antonio Sosa, and through mediation of Dr. Echevarria. (Page 75).

January 2, 1901: Collected the check sent by the Major Surgeon of
U. S. V., Mr. Read, value $20.00, covering the first month's rent on the
land of the San José farm occupied by the yellow fever experimental commission,
one-half of which was delivered to Don Antonio Sosa, lessee of the farm. (P. 84)

January 19, 1901: Paid by Major J. R. Kean, U. S. V. $20.00 American
gold, amount of the 2nd month's rent on the land of the San José farm
occupied for yellow fever experimentation, for December 10, 1900, to Jan-
uary 9, 1901. (Page 87)

February 25, 1901: Check sent for FORTY DOLLARS American gold by Major
J. R. Kean, U. S. V., Disbursing Officer, Columbia Barraks, amount of two
months' rent on land of the San José farm, in Marianao, for yellow fever
experimentation, from January 10th to March 9th, at the rate of $20.00
American gold per month. One-half for Sosa. (Page 91)

April 22, 1901: Major J. R. Kean, Surgeon, U. S. Army, Disbursing
Officer, today sent the vouchers for signature in payment of the rent on
Camp Lezar, from March 9th to May 10th, in the San José farm, Marianao. (P. 99)

June 11, 1901: Collected from Major J. R. Kean, Surgeon, U. S. Army,
Disbursing Officer, the amount of rent on land of Camp Lezar on the San José
farm, corresponding to the time from May 9th to July 10th of this year. $40.
American gold or $44.00 Spanish gold. (Page 100).

September 29, 1901: Today were returned, signed, to Major J. R. Kean,
Surgeon, U. S. A., Disbursing Officer, corresponding to the rent for two
months of the land occupied by Camp Lazear, Experimental Sanitary Camp, on
the San José farm and which became due on August 10th and September 9th.
At the rate of $20.00 American gold, per month, the amount is $40.00 gold.
(Page 116).

October 10, 1901: Today was received the last check of $20.00, amount
of the rent for Camp Lazear, on the San José Farm, which became due on the
9th, and they left the farm; leaving (delivering) the two wooden houses
which they built to carry out experiments on yellow fever and mosquitoes.
-- $22.00. (Page 117)

div1.p:
I CERTIFY that the foregoing entries, translated from the Spanish
originals into English, have been read to me and that I find them to conform
in tenor to the original entries as made by my deceased spouse, Doctor Ignacio
Rojas, in his own handwriting:

Maria Teresa Loma, Viuda de Rojas.
(Maria Teresa Loma, Widow of Dr. Rojas) HABANA, CUBA, October 19, 1940.
The ORIGINAL for Dr. Philip S. Hench, MAYO CLINIC, Rochester, Minn., U. S. A.
ONE COPY EACH FOR SEÑORA ROJAS AND SR. MORAN.
